subSense.def:
a game where
you have to find the answer to a problem
subSense.example: I can't do today's crossword puzzle

subSense.def: something that is hard to understand
subSense.example:
It's a puzzle to me why they don't go to
live in the country

subSense.def:
to be difficult
to understand
subSense.example:
It puzzles me how the
robbers managed to get away

subSense.def:
a shape with a
square base and four sides rising to meet
at a point

the seventeenth letter of
the alphabet, between P and R

something necessary for a job, e.g.
proof that you have completed a partic-
ular course of study
subSense.example:
Does she have the
right qualifications for the job?

subSense.def:
something which limits the meaning of
a statement, or shows that you do not
agree with something completely
subSense.example:
I
want to add one qualification to the
agreement: if the goods are not deliv-
ered by the 30th of June, then the order
will be cancelled

subSense.def:
success in a test or
competition which takes you on to the
next stage
subSense.example:
She didn't reach the neces-
sary standard for qualification

body.subSense:
to attach condi-
tions to something ć I must qualify the
offer by saying that your proposals still
have to be approved by the chairman.
(NOTE: qualifies -qualifying -quali-
fied)

1. how good
something is ć We want to measure the
air quality in the centre of town. ć There
are several high-quality restaurants in
the West End. (NOTE: no plural)

subSense.def:
some-
thing which is part of a person's charac-
ter
subSense.example:
She has many good qualities, but
unfortunately is extremely lazy

What
qualities do you expect in a good sales-
man?

subSense.def:
how much of
something there is

an occasion
when people argue about something
subSense.example:
They have had a quarrel and aren't
speaking to each other

I think the
quarrel was over who was in charge of
the cash desk

subSense.def:
one of four
equal parts of something
subSense.example:
She cut the
pear into quarters

The jar is only a
quarter empty

He paid only a quarter
of the normal fare because he works for
the airline

subSense.def:
the part of a harbour or
port where boats stop
subSense.note:
NOTE: Do not
confuse with key

subSense.def: the wife of a king
subSense.example:
King Charles I's queen was the
daughter of the king of France

subSense.def:
a
woman who rules a country
subSense.example:
The
Queen sometimes lives in Windsor Cas-
tle

Queen Victoria was queen for
many years
subSense.note:
NOTE: queen is spelt with
a capital letter when used before a
name or when referring to a particular
person: Queen Elizabeth I

subSense.def:
in the
game of chess, the second most impor-
tant piece, after the king
subSense.example:
In three
moves he had captured my queen

subSense.def: a question
subSense.example:
She
had to answer a mass of queries about
the tax form
subSense.note:
NOTE: The plural is que-
ries.

subSense.def:
a sen-
tence which needs an answer
subSense.example:
The
teacher couldn't answer the children's
questions

Some of the questions in
the exam were too difficult

The man-
ager refused to answer questions from
journalists about the fire

subSense.def:
a problem
or matter
subSense.example:
The question is, who do we
appoint to run the shop when we're on
holiday?

The main question is that of
cost

He raised the question of moving
to a less expensive part of town

subSense.def: to ask questions
subSense.example:
The police ques-
tioned the driver for four hours

subSense.def:
a sign (?) used in writing to show
that a question is being asked

a
printed list of questions given to people
to answer, usually questions about what
they like or what they buy

a line of people or
things such as cars, waiting one behind
the other for something
subSense.example:
There was a
queue of people waiting to get into the
exhibition

We joined the queue at the
entrance to the stadium

body.subSense:
to stand
in a line and wait for something ć We
spent hours queuing for tickets. (NOTE:
queues -queuing -queued)

subSense.def:
done with speed
or in a short time
subSense.example:
I'm trying to work
out the quickest way to get to the Tower
of London

We had a quick lunch and
then went off for a walk

He is much
quicker at calculating than I am

I am
not sure that going by air to Paris is
quicker than taking the train

subSense.def:
very fast, with-
out taking much time
subSense.example:
He ate his sup-
per very quickly because he wanted to
watch the match on TV

The firemen
came quickly when we called 999

subSense.def:
without any
noise
subSense.example: a house in a quiet street

I wish
the children would be quiet.

I'm trying
to work

subSense.def: with no great excitement
subSense.example: We had a quiet holiday by the sea

It's
a quiet little village

The hotel is in the
quietest part of the town

subSense.def:
without mak-
ing any noise
subSense.example:
The burglar climbed
quietly up to the window

She shut the
door quietly behind her

subSense.def:
to leave something
such as a job or a place and not return
subSense.example: When the boss criticised her, she quit

I'm fed up with the office, I'm thinking
of quitting

subSense.def:
to stop doing some-
thing
subSense.example: Will you quit bothering me!
He quit smoking

subSense.def: to some degree
subSense.example: It's quite a long play

She's quite a
good writer

The book is quite amus-
ing but I liked the TV play better

subSense.def:
to a
great degree
subSense.example:
You're quite mad to go
walking in a snowstorm

He's quite
right

I don't quite understand why
you want to go China

subSense.def:
a game where you are
asked a series of questions
subSense.example:
She got all
the questions right in the quiz

They
organised a general knowledge quiz

subSense.def:
the
words of one person which are repeated
by another person
subSense.example:
The article ended
with a quotation from one of Churchill's
speeches

subSense.def: a quotation
subSense.example:
I need
some good quotes from his speech to put
into my report

subSense.def:
to repeat what
someone has said or written
subSense.example:
He start-
ed his speech by quoting lines from
Shakespeare's 'Hamlet'.
